newsitem.title: UK: Digital facelift announced for British passports.
newsitem.headline: Digital facelift announced for British passports.

text.p: Britons will enter the new millennium with revamped, high security passports under a multi-million pound deal announced on Thursday.

Siemens Business Services, a British subsidiary of German industrial group Siemens AG, will work with Britain's Passport Agency to upgrade the passports, once leather-bound, using "digital printing" to store information.
The new passports should be in operation by the start of 1999.

"The threat to the security of the passport document is growing," said interior minister Mike O'Brian. "We aim to counter this with the introduction of a printed, digitised facial image of the holder and their signature in the passport book."
Siemens said it fought off computer giants IBM and Electronic Data Systems to win the contract, but would not disclose what it was worth.
"It's what you would call a multi-million pound deal - we're very pleased," said business development manager Armin Rau at Siemens Business Services.
The new passports will be printed and issued by a private company, The Stationery Office Ltd, under a second contract.
The new technology should reduce the time needed to process passport applications, enabling the current target of 10 days to be reached more consistently.
